book.title: The Proverbs, Epigrams, and Miscellanies of John Heywood

marginalia.translation: Eulogus' own library. Little, and good: 1590. For Eulogus. The essential preparation for civil elocution. 1) The Aula ciuilis Conuersationis, which is the golden foundation of an urban speech; and the actual royal profession of princely eloquence. 2) Thomas Eliot's??? 3) Stefano Guazzo, book 4 [of 'The civil conservation'], of 'a civil banquet'. 4) Roger Ascham's 'Discourse' of Charles V's political negotations. Singular, most speedily by heart. It is even useful to have Heywood's most familiar 5) general proverbs and his own epigrams. 6) Likewise Du Bartas' brightest 'song of triumph of the French king': in which nothing more lively can be read. With the delicate inner parts of all in Eunapius' 'Lives'. 7, 8) (and with Domenichi's witticisms. These are most short and greatly necessary. Since longer times it is vacant of more full and varied things. Before all things I prefer the 'Arcadia of the Countess' and the 'heroic sayings and deeds of Gargantua'. I even add to the variety of discourses, 11) the Apology of Herodotus, 12) and Manlius' common places. 13) With the most useful and sweetest strategies of Marcantonio Gandino. Others demonstrate the most fruitful living praxis of the most excellent actor in the world.
